results.notes:
Maritime chaparral on ancient stabilized sand dunes. Tiny amount of material found accidentally on twigs with Buellia oidalea (observation 242686).

Thallus barely present, grey, K-, C- (supposed to be C+R). Apothecia convex, dark reddish brown, proper margin dominant,algae limited to small patches below hypothecium. Disk and margin K+R, C-. Hypothecium seemed to have oil inspersion.

Spores polarilocular, hyaline, about 12×6µm.

results.notes: I am only confident that this is the mushroom that most often gets called Leccinum scabrum in NE NA. Associated with birch/beech/oak forests. Flesh does not bruise except for blue/green at base of stipe. Pores bruise brownish. Scabers dark brown to blackish from the beginning. Occurs in the early season in CT, June-July and then again late in season. KOH on stipe flesh yellowish. Cap brown with pale blotches as is common with the similar L. varicolor.
results.location_name: Meshomesic State Forest, Cobalt, Connecticut, USA

results.notes:
TZ #107b Tanzanian Amanita
Collection date: April 7, 2016
Collector Name: Johannes (Johann) Harnisch
Collection Identification number: TZ #107b
Collection location: Mufindi, Mafinga, Iringa, Tanzania, East Africa. GPS -8.440950 35.096990
2 specimens collected for this description, 1 button and 1 expanding button, these seemed to be attacked by a mold, collected under 3 needle pine. Growing in groups or solitary under pine.
Medium to large sized Amanita of the muscaria group.
Total height: 130mm (expanding button), 42mm thick at stipe midspan.
Pileus: red orange, convex expanding, flesh in upper ½ or 1/3 of pileus bright yellow toned, otherwise white and unchanging.
Lamellae: dull white,
Universal veil on pileus leaving dull white patches.
Stipe: white, thick, interior stuffed, equal, dry, 71mm long x 42 mm thick,
Ring present, white,
Bulbous base: dull white, coated with patches of universal veil. Globular base, 45mm diameter.
Odor faint.
results.location_name: Mufindi, Mafinga, Iringa, Tanzania

results.notes:
This is a collection of the Amanita muscaria group I found in Tanzania
see also this observation http://mushroomobserver.org/242703
results.location_name: Mufindi, Mafinga, Iringa, Tanzania

results.notes:
And unexpectedly I was facing an unusual variety of lichens with perithecia. They all lived in a group of a dozen of trees (mostly oaks) at the entrance of a protected park, but still in the outside. Till now I could identify the following species:
- Mycoporum antecellens,
- Arthpyrenia analepta;
- Arthopyrenia cineropruinosa.
One of the specimens of this last species was overgrown by another one with similar shaped spores but smaller in size. I think it could be Arthopyrenia salicis, but not certain.
Of this species I only found before the second in the list, but a very reduced specimen growing together with a Graphis sp. (Observation 211672).
This observation is devoted to the second one in the above list; the first one, Mycoporum antecellens, was considered at observation 242632.

results.notes:
On intruded siliceous rock in a semi-arid grassland setting.

This is a large grey crust on siliceous rock, common. Thallus blue-grey, pruinose, areoles separated but continuous, with dark sides, prothallus not apparent, K-. Apothecia are uncommon on this sample, immersed, margin slightly raised, same color as thallus, sometimes with a thin white rim, disk black without pruina. Pycnidia common, 1 or more per areole. Epihymenium greenish blue, turning brown in K. Hymenium hyaline, persistently blue in IKI.

Asci appear to be 8 spored, but most were immature and hard to tell. Spores hyaline, simple, ellipsoid. No mature spore measurements. Conidia mostly in the 18-20+µm range, straight.

Uncommonly with Lichenostigma elongatum (observation 242884) as a thallus and apothecia parasite.
results.location_name: Monterey Co., California, USA

results.notes: This mushroom was found on a forest road in Sweden. The mushroom was very thin and tough.

results.notes:
Parasitic lichenicolous fungi occurring on Aspicilia cyanescens (observation 242882).

Thallus appears as black strands on apothecia and thallus, sometimes in a radiating pattern. At 1000x in K, the cells are round and brown. Did not get a look at the ascomata, but apparently crushed one in the mount and found asci and spores.

Asci globose, spores 1-septate, slightly brown, appearing halonate and hyaline when young
results.location_name: Monterey Co., California, USA

results.notes:
Parasitic lichenicolous fungi on Caloplaca subsoluta (observation 242919), also occurring directly on the sandstone rock. The fungi occurs as tiny black dots superficial on the lichen host or adjacent rock. In section, it looks like an amorphous blob of cells at 400x, but at 1000x you can see what I think are brown 1-septate spores.

I don’t know much about this one yet, but see observation 91142 for more info from Jason Hollinger. This species was described in 2010 by Knudsen, not long ago!

results.notes:
Found in grass and moss under a white pine in the area around the Deer Browse shelters. It has not rained for a week and the ground is dry but not parched. Same for the mushroom.

The pores are more orange and yellow than true red, but still blue extremely fast. The cap and stem are much more tan than the yellow-with-red-highlights I’ve been finding in the same area under the oaks. Just like those specimens, the main effect of ammonia was to bleach away the bluing all around the drop.

No hairs by the base, Nor any reticulation. No unusual smells, tastes, or textures.

results.notes:
General Notes:
> This is the third time I collect this species from the same exact site/location – see obs 141832 from VIII-04-13 and obs 170841 from VII-20-14; the latter includes spore measurements. However, neither of the earlier collections was saved.
> One young and one old basidiocarps fruiting under several mature oaks. The trees themselves are growing in a small, rectangular parcel of land (~12 × 5 meters) circumscribed by a paved road, a paved parking lot and dirt trails. Beyond that immediate area, there are more old oaks and other mature deciduous trees, but no conifers.
> The pictures give an accurate presentation of the colors.
> The cap surface readily stains blackish-blue; the non-reticulate stipe surface stains dark blue.
> Chemical Tests:
KOH = maroon on cap surface; deep rusty orange on contexts and even darker on the tubes/pore surface (see pix)
Ammonia = mahogany on cap surface; medium amber brown on context (see pix)
FeSO4 = olive on cap surface; erased the bluing on context; blotted context was grayish-yellow

DNA Sequencing Results (last updated 21-Jan-19):
> A clean and contiguous nrLSU sequence of 1287 bps was obtained from this material by Dr. Kudzma. Unfortunately, the first ~157 nucleotides from the 5’ end had to be edited out for quality control. The missing region includes the LR0R, ITS4 and ITS6R primers that together account for 56 nucleotides. There are no ambiguous characters, it’s a single haplotype.
This sequence is a 100% match to the overlapping/aligned regions in the LSUs of obs 206608, obs 212359, obs 244427, obs 251141, and obs 287453.
> A clean and contiguous TEF-1-alpha sequence of 607 bps was also procured by Dr. Kudzma. The sequenced region is between and including the EF1-983 and EF-1567R primers. There are no ambiguous characters, it’s a single haplotype.
Careful comparison of this TEF-1-α sequence with those of obs 206608, obs 212359, obs 244427, obs 251141, and obs 288090 shows that the sequences are essentially identical. The differences are present as a small and variable number of single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) events at 7 specific positions shared between these organisms. Below is a summary of all numbered hetero-sites for these 6 collections (“R” = A & G; “Y” = C & T); the base count in this alignment starts from the 1st character of the EF1-983F primer:
………………….30…..108…..422…..443…..489…..590…..599
206608………Y………C……….R………..Y………G………C……….C
243052………T………C……….G…….…C………G………C….…….C
244427………Y………C……….A……….Y………G……….Y…….…C
251141………Y………C……….A……….T………G……….C….……C
212358………Y………C……….R……….Y………R….……C.………C
288090………Y………Y……….R……….Y………G…….…C.………Y
As can be seen from the above table, only 243052 is represented by a single TEF-1-α haplotype (no ambiguities), while 251141 with a single “Y” has two, 206608 & 24427 have eight, 212358 has sixteen, and 288090 (with 5 SNPs) has up to 32 haplotypes in the sequenced stretch of the gene. Since the observed ambiguity profiles for positions 422 and 443 are unique, not a single haplotype variant is shared by all collections. For example, the single haplotype of 243052 is present only in 206608, 212358 and 288090.
Discussion (last updated 20-Jan-19):
Based on the genetic data discussed above, this collection represents one of several existing phenotypic variants (morphotypes) of the most common and widespread hardwood-associated red-pored bolete species found in eastern North America. The extreme phenotypic plasticity observed in this species can be readily appreciated from the images of the other 5 sequenced collections.
For further information on this taxon, such as phylogenetic trees, see the notes in obs 206608.

results.notes:
Two pairs of fruiting bodies growing two feet apart from each other on a steep slope between a dirt trail and the creek. The nearby trees were all hardwoods: red and white oaks and beech.
First I thought these were B. subvelutipes (based on cap colors); however, I couldn’t see any red or yellow hairs on stipe bases and the stipe coloration had little red in it. Now I am thinking these are closer to obs 243052, despite the notable difference in cap colors, as there was a decent amount of yellow pigment in the cap of one of the fbs from the second pair (see pic). The chemical tests were also in excellent agreement with those of the aforementioned obsie:
KOH = maroon on cap surface; deep rusty orange on context
NH3 = mahogany to dark brown on cap surface; medium amber brown on context
FeSO4 = dark gray on cap surface; changed the bluing on context to yellow; blotted context was grayish-yellow.

results.notes:
Hebeloma crustuliniforme (Bull.) Quél., Cortinariaceae, Agaricales
(Poison Pie = Гебелома клейкая или хреновый гриб)

Cap: 3-7 cm wide, convex and often with indistinct wide knob then wide convex up to almost flatten with indistinct knob; whitish or yellowish-white minor orange-white up to dull orange-brown or light yellowish-brown when very old; margins are lighter than a cap top; surface smooth or glossy (slimy when wet);. Flesh is white when young, then brownish. Odour is unpleasant.
Gills: almost free or attached with notched edge (pinching out end), whitish or light cream or some pinkish up to light brownish-pink or reddish-brown when old, close and narrow up to moderately broad with short and very short additional gills, often reddish-brown tiny drops of juice.
Stalk: 3.5-7 cm long, 0.6-1.5cm thick, slightly fibrous and hollow (when old), white or whitish up to yellowish-white; upper half is somewhat hairy and silky.
Edibility: poisonous or not edible.
Habitat: scattered small groups in pine-tree forest with some birches
Season: June-August

results.notes:
Found in grass and moss under oak in the area just below “mushroom vale.” It had not rained for until a brief but good 1-hour dousing yesterday. The ground was still a bit dry, and based on the lack of chanterelles I think it would have been thoroughly baked if we’d come before the rain.

Four specimens were found. This observation is one of the younger ones. The older one has been moved to its own entry (observation 243109) for the sake of thoroughness. I have no doubt they are all the same even though the older one was found 10 feet away from the others, by the trunk of the tree instead of the drip line.

First things first: this is an intensely desirable mushroom, with the sort of scent and texture that makes boletes so much fun. The older one is slightly less dense than the younger specimens, but it is still very firm and “cheeselike” without being sticky. All specimens felt oddly heavy and cool in the hand.

Cap and stem are red over yellow. Pores are bright yellow and very, very small. Tube layer is exceptionally thin, approximately 1 mm deep compared to the 9 mm context. Cap is 5 cm in diameter.

The cap context was pale yellow, the stipe context full yellow, and the base yellow with a heavy amount of red from larval tunnels. The chemicals had a stronger result at each level.

Lots of spots and lines on the stipe, but nothing at all like a pattern of reticulation. Taste and smell unremarkable but really good.

A note on lighting The photos taken on the table are about 2 hours after picking. Except where noted, it’s natural light on a very overcast afternoon.

A note on chemical reactions All the ammonia reactions were very weak if they existed at all. The KOH reactions were more profound, but still not striking. Iron salts had a very ready reaction, which differs from other “bicolor” observations such as observation 242587. All of the chemical reactions got stronger as the test moved from cap context to mid-stipe context to lower context.

Ammonia on Cap Skin: Yellow
Ammonia on Stipe Skin: Yellow
Ammonia on Pores: Yellow
Ammonia on Cap Context: No reaction
Ammonia on Stipe Context: No reaction, or might have darkened a bit in the lower portions.

KOH on Cap Skin: Yellow.
KOH on Stipe Skin: Orange
KOH on Pores: Orange.
KOH on Cap Context: Yellow to pale orange.
KOH on Stipe Context: Full orange in the yellow parts, and red-brown further down where there are red larval tunnels.

FeCl3 on Cap Skin: Olive green.
FeCl3 on Stipe Skin: Light olive green.
FeCl3 on Pores: Olive green.
FeCl3 on Cap Context: Pale olive green.
FeCl3 on Stipe Context: Dark olive green.

results.notes:
This is the older companion of the mushroom described at observation 243105. The only real differences between the two are the color of the cap context (this was white with a bare hint of yellow, and that was pale yellow), and the proportion of context to tubes (this was about 2.5:1 and that was 9:1). The whole mushroom was accordingly just a bit less dense, though even this older one was very noticeably solid and “cheeselike” compared to other boletes.

Found in grass and moss under oak in the area just below “mushroom vale.” It had not rained for until a brief but good 1-hour dousing yesterday. The ground was still a bit dry, and based on the lack of chanterelles I think it would have been thoroughly baked if we’d come before the rain.

Four specimens were found. This observation is the oldest and the only mature specimen. It was by the trunk of the tree, about 10 feet away from the younger specimens. I have no doubt they are all the same species.

First things first: this is an intensely desirable mushroom, with the sort of scent and texture that makes boletes so much fun. The older one is slightly less dense than the younger specimens, but it is still very firm and “cheesecake” without being sticky. All specimens felt oddly heavy and cool in the hand.

Cap and stem are red over yellow, with the cap largely faded toward tan. Pores are bright yellow and very, very small. Tube layer is exceptionally thin, approximately 5 mm deep compared to the 12 mm context. Cap is 13 cm in diameter and relatively flat on top. (Apologies – like a dummy I failed to take a picture of the cap skin).

The cap context was a very pale yellow (even whiter than the younger specimens), the stipe context full yellow, and the base yellow with a heavy amount of red from larval tunnels. The chemicals had a stronger result at each level.

Lots of spots and lines on the stipe, but nothing at all like a pattern of reticulation. Taste and smell unremarkable but really good. Less dense than the younger specimens, but the difference is well within normal parameters.

A note on lighting The photos taken on the table are about 2 hours after picking. Except where noted, it’s natural light on a very overcast afternoon. For whatever reason this lighting seems to have called up more of the cool colors and made the warmer yellows less apparent.

A note on chemical reactions All the ammonia reactions were very weak if they existed at all. The KOH reactions were more profound, but still not striking. Iron salts had a very ready reaction, which differs from other “bicolor” observations such as observation 242587. All of the chemical reactions got stronger as the test moved from cap context to mid-stipe context to lower context.

Ammonia on Cap Skin: No reaction
Ammonia on Stipe Skin: Yellow or no reaction
Ammonia on Pores: Yellow to light orange
Ammonia on Cap Context: Yellow or no reaction
Ammonia on Stipe Context: No reaction, or might have darkened a bit in the lower portions.

KOH on Cap Skin: Light orange
KOH on Stipe Skin: Orange
KOH on Pores: Orange-red.
KOH on Cap Context: Yellow to pale orange.
KOH on Stipe Context: Full orange in the yellow parts, and red-brown further down where there are red larval tunnels.

FeCl3 on Cap Skin: Olive green or gray.
FeCl3 on Stipe Skin: Olive green or gray.
FeCl3 on Pores: Olive green.
FeCl3 on Cap Context: Pale olive green.
FeCl3 on Stipe Context: Dark olive green.

results.notes:
In mixed woods. Oak, Hickory, Ash, Maple, and Hemlock. Caps 11/4"-21/4" wide, tuberculate-striate. Cuticle peels almost to the disc. Flesh white unchanging, and no reaction to KOH. Taste was oily but very hot after about 20 seconds; odor was rancid when specimen crushed. Stipe 1-21/4″ × 3/8-1/2" @ apex, equal to tapered towards base, and hollow.
R. subfoetens has flesh that turns bright golden yellow in KOH.
R. laurocerasi taste is unpleasant and hot, and has an odor of bitter almonds, and the margin is sulcate.
R. fragrantissima has an oily acrid taste. This specimen was burning the tip of my tongue, but wasn’t as hot as other mushrooms that I tasted. No spores obtained.

results.notes:
Morchella sect. Distantes Boud., Morchellaceae, Pezizales (Morchella conica = сморчок конический)
Cap is 2-3cm wide, 4-6cm high, elongate and narrowly conical, wrinkled, reddish-brown up to dark reddish-brown longitudinal and radial ribs and long pits with cross dividers attached to stalk. Flesh is brittle and hollow.
Stalk: 3-5 cm long and 1.5-2.5cm thick, hollow, fluted with some soil at bottom.
Stalk turned into a cap without a ledge. Other similar kinds have a ledge or much longer stalk.
Habitat: rare kind, small groups or single in pine-tree forest with rare birches.
Season: May.
Edibility: good (boiling recommended cause sand).

results.notes:
Found in grass and moss under oak by the North Pine shelter. I thought it might be something else because it differed a bit from the bicolors I’ve found earlier this year. Specifically, there was:

  • a bit more yellow on the stipe
  • the stipe was more “openly” marked with stripes and spots (no reticulation)
  • the cap context was as yellow as the stipe context, rather than paler
  • the flesh and pores blued readily if slowly (5-10 seconds) and temporarily (the bluing faded after 15 minutes or so)
  • there was a smell of – wait for it – fenugreek, which is a major ingredient in curry.

All that made me think B. sensibilis. But the chemical tests moved it back to Baorangia bicolor, especially after I remembered that the Mushroom Expert article specifically noted that many bicolors have that smell, while a lot of sensibilis specimens do not. The context of B. sensibilis is supposed to turn yellow/orange or yellow/brown with iron salts, but this clearly turned more of a gray/green, which is consistent with bicolor instead.

Cap and stem are red over yellow. Pores are bright yellow and very, very small. Tube layer is exceptionally thin, well under a tenth of the context layer (OTOH, it is also a very young mushroom).

The cap and stipe context were full, bright yellow and reacted equally to the chemical tests. Mycelium was white.

Lots of spots and lines on the stipe, but nothing at all like a pattern of reticulation. Taste was unremarkable, but there was a faint smell of curry.

A note on lighting The photos seem true to me. They were taken in the shade on a bright sunny afternoon.

A note on chemical reactions All the ammonia reactions were very weak if they existed at all. The KOH reactions were more profound, but still not striking. Iron salts had a very ready reaction.

Ammonia on Cap Skin: No strong reaction
Ammonia on Stipe Skin: No reaction
Ammonia on Pores: No reaction
Ammonia on Cap Context: No reaction
Ammonia on Stipe Context: No reaction, or might have darkened a bit by the base.

results.notes:
Scattered small groups and isolated basidiomes growing gregariously under a large pin oak and mature white pines. Odor earthy-fungal. The dingy yellow flesh didn’t stain blue (maybe a hint of blue right above the tubes), but the tubes did. The stipe flesh was damaged at the bottom and mostly brown, so that I couldn’t verify the existence of carrot orange dots found in H. campestris and H. rubellus.
Chemical Tests:
KOH = Amber brown on pileipellis; orangish-brown on context and dark brown on tubes
NH3 = Amber brown on pileipellis (lighter than KOH); negative to darker yellow on context
FeSO4 = Grayish-olive on pileipellis; negative to grayish on context

results.notes: A gregarious fruiting in poor rocky soil at the edge of a suburban sidewalk. These tiny fruit bodies range in size from 1.5 – 2.0 cm. wide and 1.0 – 1.5 cm. high and are without any sterile base. The young fruit bodies are covered with a white, finely granular surface which seems to dissolve away revealing a smooth yellow covering that darkens to brown in maturity. The interior is yellow initially, then develops/deteriorates into an olive-yellow color and finally into a wet, olive-brown spore mass.

results.notes:
Found in grass under oak. The area had a wide variety of other boletes from several genera.

There are problems with calling it B. pallidus. The pores did not bruise and the chemical tests are off. The cap of pallidus is supposed to turn rusty orange with both ammonia and iron salts. No reaction here. And the pores are supposed to turn gray-green with ammonia. Again, no reaction.

My alternative ID was T. intermedius, but there’s no bitter taste unless you let your imagination work on you, there appears to be some white netting, and there was no reaction to iron salts. My worry is that the bitter taste will develop as it dries and then ambush my next sauce…

T. indecisus also has issues because there was no reaction to ammonia (maybe a slight pinking of the pores) and the supposedly strong KOH reaction was missing too.

results.notes:
Evidence of mycophagy led me to this truffle location. The two were found side by side and were surrounded by more immature specimens. Over story trees were subalpine fir (Abies lasiocarpa) dominant. The understory veg. Was absent. The peridium was very knobby and brain like. The Gleba was pure white and densely packed. As the truffle began to dry it emitted a “truffly” odor comparable to Geopora cooperi.
When the truffle was squeezed a white, gooey exudate emerged from the gleba and turned powdery and chalky as it dried.

results.notes:
Two specimens are in a personnel herbarium. Two of these truffles were found together near a Doug fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii) and western Hemlock (Tsuga heterophylla). Evidence if mycophagy was present. These truffles were at least an inch long and smell heavily of some undefinable odor. My best description is that they smelled sharply of drying asphalt tar.
Dark brown Gleba with dirt, brown peridium. Threads or rhizomorphs were present on the bottoms, likely making them Rhizopogon species.

results.notes: Found near Pseudotsuga menziesii, Abies grandis, Pinus contorta, mahonia repens. Mycophagy taking place led my to the location. The truffle was found with its top peaking just above mineral soil. The specimen was a very dirty light brown and was very firm as well. The Gleba was unlike any I have seen. It was mostly smooth with only the occasional hole or locule present as a result of a loosely folded area. The brick red Gleba was squiggly looking and without any distinct odor. Hyphae were on the truffles bottom. This specimen was of good size and measured over an inch long. The white columella was only present in the truffles center.

results.notes:
From what I’ve read of this species, this fruiting sounds very typical: hot summer day in July in Orange County, Southern California. It was growing in the corner of a patch of soil in a grocery store parking lot, and looking impressively robust and fleshy despite the lack of any sort of recent rain in the area. There may be sprinklers in the area, though I forgot to check. Very glad to finally see this mushroom for the first time, I was fascinated by the idea of a green-spored mushrooms when first learning about it many years ago!

Description: the mushrooms were very willing to shed their cap scales on everything they touched, edges of cap very frayed. The gill color of the older two mushrooms was distinctively pale green, while less so for the younger. The spore print of the younger one (not pictured) was surprisingly more cream than anything, with white bits but no hint of green like in the older mushroom’s print which is pictured. Stipe light above the veil, dark below. Very distinctive dark orange to brown coloration where the caps and stalks were separated, similar to C. rhacodes, noticed about an hour after I picked the mushrooms and inspected them at home.
results.location_name: Hanson's Shopping Center on Del Obispo, San Juan Capistrano, Orange Co., California, USA
